Title: Talking Loud Or Talking Often: How the Interplay Between Network Structure and Agent Influence Affects the Time to Reach Consensus in Collective Decision-Making
Description: Consensus-seeking processes are core mechanisms for social organization in non-human animal groups, human societies, artificial and multi-agent systems. Such processes consist of a series of negotiations between individuals, which ultimately aggregate different individual opinions into one common agreed decision. Related works have shown that a small number of influential and highly centralized agents i.e. leaders, considerably speed up the consensus-seeking process. Yet the important features of hierarchy and leaders have not been clearly identified and their investigation in experiments provide contradictory evidence. To disentangle these effects, we separate two features of hierarchy (i) the level of centralization ν and (ii) the number of leaders NL, i.e. influential individuals. We therefore developed a continuous opinion formation model to explore the effect of each feature and their interplay on the time to reach a global consensus. The results show that the most important feature is the topology of the network structure, with higher centralization always decreasing the time to reach consensus. In addition, it also demonstrates that the effect of influential individuals are deeply entangled with the underlying network structure. Indeed, it can be beneficial to have a few leaders if the structure is centralized, but surprisingly it can also be detrimental if the population is homogeneous. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation of the “babble” hypothesis which stresses the importance of talkativeness and extraversion of leaders. Further directions involve a full characterization of the main mechanisms leading to polarization or fragmentation as final states in more complex network structures, such as modular structures with nested hierarchies.
Name: Cedric Perret
Biography: I am a French guy doing my 2nd year of PhD on the evolutionary origins of social organization. I am currently in the Computing School at Edinburgh Napier University but I originally did a master in evolutionary biology in France and USA. My broad research interests lie in the evolution of social behaviour and social organization. I love having endless debate on science, politics and random topics around 1 or 16 good pints. Also, reading SF, hiking, video games and especially trying new stuff!

Title: Characterizing Atrial Fibrillation Dynamics using Multiplex Visibility Graphs
Description: We performed simulations of normal rhythm and fibrillatory dynamics using the mono-domain formulation of the Rogers and McCulloch model. Clinical data were recorded from 4 patients with atrial fibrillation before and after successful catheter ablation procedure using a multi-electrode basket catheter. From multivariate times series of simulated and clinical data, we constructed multiplex visibility graphs. We then compared the structural properties of multiplex visibility graphs between time series from healthy and fibrillatory rhythms. For both simulations and clinical data, the giant component of the multiplex visibility graph was higher in time series of normal rhythm compared to time series of fibrillatory rhythms. The structural efficiency of the multiplex graphs was higher in normal rhythm compared to fibrillatory rhythms. Multiplex visibility graphs provide novel insights in cardiac dynamics, paving the way for a more in-depth characterization of fibrillatory rhythms. In particular, normal sinus rhythm is associated with multiplex visibility graphs that have greater connectivity and structural efficiency compared to fibrillatory dynamics. Our long-term goal is to develop a network-based method that could be used to define procedural end-points and identify alternative therapeutic targets.
Name: Andrea Santoro
Biography: I am a second year PhD student in Applied Mathematics at the Queen Mary University of London. My PhD project aims to develop new measures, based on optimization principles and information theory techniques, to extract relevant features from large-scale multilayer networks. I studied mathematics (both BSc and MSc) at the University of Catania, Italy. I was also a student of the 'Scuola Superiore di Catania', a public institution that provides university students with advanced additional courses.

Title: Quantifying Transmission and Identifying Factors Associated with the Malaria Outbreak in Venezuela
Description: Our analyses provide a quantitative examination of the current malaria outbreak, both within Venezuela, and its impact on neighboring countries.
Name: Cesar Montalvo

I had the opportunity to work with immigrants. I lived and worked in the Czech Republic. Then, I worked at the office of the President in Ecuador for 5 years. Convinced defender of Citizen Revolution. I am a PhD student at Arizona State University in Applied Math. I want to devote my future career to education, mentoring and the public sphere.

Description: Development of ventricular tachycardia and degeneration of it into ventricular fibrillation can be considered a phase transition in cardiac dynamics. Title: Thresholding Normally Distributed Data Creates Complex Networks
Description: Network data sets are often constructed by some kind of thresholding procedure. The resulting networks frequently possess properties such as heavy-tailed degree distributions, non-zero clustering, large connected components and short average shortest path lengths. These properties are considered typical of complex networks and appear in many contexts, prompting consideration of their universality. Here we introduce a very simple model for continuous valued relational data and study the effect of thresholding it. We find that some, but not all, of the properties associated with complex networks can be seen after thresholding, even when the underlying data is not “complex”.

Biography: Hi! My name is Jordan and I'm a PhD candidate in Applied Math at UC Davis. Indeed, it can be beneficial to have a few leaders if the structure is centralized, but surprisingly it can also be detrimental if the population is homogeneous. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation of the “babble” hypothesis which stresses the importance of talkativeness and extraversion of leaders. Further directions involve a full characterization of the main mechanisms leading to polarization or fragmentation as final states in more complex network structures, such as modular structures with nested hierarchies.
Name: Andrea Santoro
Biography: I am a second year PhD student in Applied Mathematics at the Queen Mary University of London. My PhD project aims to develop new measures, based on optimization principles and information theory techniques, to extract relevant features from large-scale multilayer networks. I studied mathematics (both BSc and MSc) at the University of Catania, Italy. I was also a student of the 'Scuola Superiore di Catania', a public institution that provides university students with advanced additional courses.

Title: Collective Information Processing in Human Rumor Spreading Networks: An experimental Study of Rumor Content Fusion and Propagation
Description: We posit that this difference is largely due to the fact that classical laboratory experiments do not take into account complex interaction mechanisms in human societies. Namely, ways in which groups can combine noisy information to reduce overall uncertainty. We design an experimental setup intended to allow the observation and quantification of such mechanisms, which have been shown to be important in other collective information processing systems. The effect of feedback introduced into the rumor spreading process through redundant transmission pathways in a network structure is investigated. The scale of our experiments is not large enough to give statistically significant results with regards to the importance of network structure However, motif analysis of our results shows that non-trivial information fusion mechanisms are employed by human participants when presented with con accounts of a rumor. We hope that the work presented in this report will pave the way to future experiments and models of information fusion, which will allow us to quantify how human societies collectively process information in the form of rumors.
Name: Zohar Neu
Biography: Zohar is a PhD student at the University of Bristol. He is a mathematician by training and currently works on the design of self-organisation algorithms for robotics and active particles. In his spare time he enjoys creative writing and playing bass guitar.

Title: Collective Information Processing in Human Rumor Spreading Networks: An experimental Study of Rumor Content Fusion and Propagation

Title: Mean First Saturation Time (MFST) and its Application to Refugee Movement
Description: In this network, nodes are cities or refugee camps, and edges denote the distance between them. We model refugees as random walkers who are biased towards the refugee camps which can hold sj people. To determine the source nodes (i) and the initial number of random walkers (n), we use data on where the conflicts happened and the number of refugees that arrive at any camp under a twomonth period after the start of the conflict. With such information, we divide the early stage of the Burundi 2015 conflict into two waves of refugees. Using the first wave of refugees we calibrate the biased parameter β of the random walk to best match the distribution of refugees on the camps. Then, we test the prediction of the distribution of refugees in camps for the second wave using the same biased parameters. Our results show that the biased random walk can capture, to some extent, the distribution of refugees in different camps (see figure 1). Finally, we test the probability of saturation for various camps. Our model suggests the saturation of one or two camps (Nakivale and Nyarugusu) when in reality only Nyarugusu camp saturated.
Topic_isced: Social and behavioural science; Mathematics and statistics
Name: R. Marıa del Rıo-Chanona
Biography: María is currently doing her Dphil in Mathematics under the supervision of Prof. Doyne Farmer. She obtained her BSc in Physics at Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México (UNAM) 2011-2016. Her research interests include networks, financial contagion and agent-based modelling of the labour market.

Title: Analysis of Neural Networks Based on Global and Local Sampling of RNA Sequences
Description: In this work, we use a new sampling approach where we first uniformly sample sequences from different distant parts of the sequence space using RNARedPrint. We then increase the size of the network by locally sampling sequences around each of the sequences sampled at first. In order to keep the network in a reasonable size, we additionally constrain the neutrality criterion such that not only the secondary structure but also the value of its folding energy is considered, using only the lowest 5% of folding energy values. This is done for three different type of structures, an artificial short hairpin structure, a Hammerhead ribozyme and a tRNA. We analyze the structure of the resulting networks and compare with already existing work. We are able to confirm earlier results and show that our sampling technique helps to explore distinct parts of the fitness landscape. We also show that local minima consist of more than one sequence and low folding energy sequences are spread throughout the network and separated by sequences with higher folding energy.
Name: Alice C. Schwarze
Biography: PhD student in math bio, currently a visiting graduate researcher at UCLA. Currently I am working models of robustness and redundancy in biological networks with a focus on applications in network pharmacology. Other things that I dabbled with (or still do): gene- and protein-interaction networks, network sampling, random matrix theory, control theory. I am a nerd for math and the natural sciences, but just as much for hiking and birds.

Title: Thresholding Normally Distributed Data Creates Complex Networks
Description: Network data sets are often constructed by some kind of thresholding procedure. The resulting networks frequently possess properties such as heavy-tailed degree distributions, non-zero clustering, large connected components and short average shortest path lengths. We find that some, but not all, of the properties associated with complex networks can be seen after thresholding, even when the underlying data is not “complex”.

Title: Evolution of Water Narratives in Local US Newspapers: A Case Study of Utah and Georgia
Description: This study leverages recent advancements in natural language processing (NLP) methods to characterize and understand patterns in water narratives, specifically in 4 local newspapers in Utah and Georgia. Analysis of the corpus identified coherent topics on a variety of water resources issues, including weather and pollution (Figure 1). Closer inspection of the topics revealed temporal and spatial variations in coverage, with a topic on hurricanes exhibiting cyclical patterns whereas a topic on tribal issues showed coverage predominantly in the western newspapers. We also analyzed the dataset for sentiments, identifying similar categories of words on trust and fear emerging in the narratives across newspaper sources. An analysis of novelty, transience, and resonance using Kullback-Leibler Divergence techniques revealed that topics with high novelty generally contained high transience and marginally high resonance over time.
Name: Conor Finn
Biography: I am a PhD student in complex systems at The University of Sydney. I work on the theoretical foundations of information theory with the aim of addressing some of the present shortcomings of multivariate information theory. I am also involved in applying some of this theoretical work in areas such as neuroscience. Outside of academia, I enjoy powerlifting, cycling and enjoying a craft beer in the park :)

Title: A Quantitative Approach to Contact Improvisation Dance
Description:
Partner improvisation is characterized by prediction, adaptation and emergent outcomes that are
unique to the pair. These definitions have not been stringently applied to improvisational dance,
therefore we propose a way to measure the influence of partners on the emergent movements of
each other. As a pilot study, we use a simple alphabet of body contact (torso, arms, legs) to code
3 videos of improvisation pairs. We record the point of contact for each partner, and then use this
information to compute measures of mutual information and entropy rate. We find that mutual
information between partners is higher as the level of the improvisation grows, which is consistent
with our understanding of prediction in improvisation. Our study finds that the level of experience
in contact improvisation of the annotator makes a difference when scoring the contact between
partners. Entropy rate calculations have a big bias due to shortage of data, and do not distinguish
between the pairs of dancers.
Name: Ariadna Venegas-Li
Biography: I’m a PhD student in physics at UC Davis. My current research focuses on understanding structure in quantum processes, but my research interests revolve widely around how to develop and use tools to properly understand, describe and predict complex systems (a shout-out to biological systems). Some things I enjoy are stories, music and the outdoors.

Title: Characterizing Atrial Fibrillation Dynamics using Multiplex Visibility Graphs
Description: We performed simulations of normal rhythm and fibrillatory dynamics using the mono-domain formulation of the Rogers and McCulloch model. Clinical data were recorded from 4 patients with atrial fibrillation before and after successful catheter ablation procedure using a multi-electrode basket catheter. From multivariate times series of simulated and clinical data, we constructed multiplex visibility graphs. We then compared the structural properties of multiplex visibility graphs between time series from healthy and fibrillatory rhythms. For both simulations and clinical data, the giant component of the multiplex visibility graph was higher in time series of normal rhythm compared to time series of fibrillatory rhythms. The structural efficiency of the multiplex graphs was higher in normal rhythm compared to fibrillatory rhythms. Multiplex visibility graphs provide novel insights in cardiac dynamics, paving the way for a more in-depth characterization of fibrillatory rhythms. In particular, normal sinus rhythm is associated with multiplex visibility graphs that have greater connectivity and structural efficiency compared to fibrillatory dynamics. Our long-term goal is to develop a network-based method that could be used to define procedural end-points and identify alternative therapeutic targets.
Name: Anastasiya Salova
Biography: I am a student from Russia currently in a physics PhD program at UC Davis. My research interests include understanding, predicting, and controlling collective behavior in complex systems.

Name: Ariadna Venegas-Li
Biography: I’m a PhD student in physics at UC Davis. Title: Investigating Phase Transitions in a Cardiac System through Informational Properties of Renewal Process Models
Description: Development of ventricular tachycardia and degeneration of it into ventricular fibrillation can be considered a phase transition in cardiac dynamics. Characterization of the underlying physical mechanisms may lead to better prediction of the onset of this phase transition and enable efficient treatment of patients at risk. Aiming to contribute to this characterization we study time series of activity in simulated heart tissue. We use Bayesian structural inference to find the best fit models in a set of hidden Markov models representing renewal processes. We compute the entropy rate and statistical complexity of these models and compare between results for healthy heart activity, heart activity at the onset of the phase transition and heart activity after the phase transition. We discuss the advantages and shortcomings of this approach, as well as alternative improvements.

Name: Anastasiya Salova

Title: Scaling of Sensory Information Intake in Organisms
Description: The metabolic resources required by organisms are known to scale with their mass raised to the 3/4 power. Like energy and nutrients, information about the environment is also a necessary resource for life. However, little attention has been placed on how the capacity to absorb information scales with size. We have taken steps toward answering this question by a) synthesizing data on sensory capacity from multiple organisms to try and answer the question empirically and b) exploring theoretical considerations that might allow us to deduce the scaling laws from first principles. We hypothesize that as organisms increase in size and complexity, their sensory capacity per unit mass decreases, owing to the fact that less total information is needed if it can be processed in a more sophisticated manner. Preliminary results, both theoretical and empirical, are supportive of this claim. In particular, we derive a fundamental bound on the sensory capacity of a spherical cell arising from the heat it dissipates, which turns out to be a linear function of the cell radius r. As the mass of a cell scales as r3, our bound implies that the maximum achievable channel capacity per unit mass decreases with the size of the organism. We also investigate the hypothesis that organisms at all scales devote a fixed fraction of their metabolic rate to gathering sensory information, and find tentative support for this claim.
Name: Elan Stopnitzky
Biography: My research sits at the intersection of information theory, statistical physics, and biology. I am more broadly passionate about wildlife, world music, literature, and effective altruism.

Title: Fluctuations in 1D Point Patterns
Description: Random point patterns with similar apparent characteristics (such as density of points) may display very different behaviours when it comes to the way these points are distributed in space. Strongly negatively correlated points (e.g. due to repulsive forces) show a high degree of order, whereas strongly positively correlated points (e.g. due to attractive forces) show clustering and hence, a high degree of disorder. These two extreme cases define a spectrum where point patterns are classified according to their fluctuations from small fluctuations (order, hyperuniformity) to large fluctuations (disorder, clustering). Point patterns with weak correlations show the same trend in their fluctuations as the typical uncorrelated case and are said to display Poisson-like behaviour. In this report, we show numerical results on different one-dimensional point patterns both computer generated and experimentally obtained (heartbeat recordings). Furthermore, we regard the case of anomalously suppressed fluctuations (hyperuniformity) as a case of special interest and we try to derive the underlying mechanisms that give rise to this behaviour. We study the Dirichlet distribution as a model that can be tuned to display any behaviour from a periodic signal to a clustered signal.
Name: Rosalba Garcia-Millan
Biography: I am on the second year of my PhD in Mathematical Physics at Imperial College London.

Name: George Cantwell
Biography: I'm originally from the UK and I've been in the US for the last few years as a graduate student. I'm working on my PhD in physics and I study complex networks. My interests are pretty broad, but I've been spending my own time on questions about the basic mathematical structure of networks.

Name: Guillaume St-Onge
Biography: PhD candidate in Physics and Network Science at Laval University in Quebec, Canada. Some of my current research interests : contagion processes on networks, networks evolution and inference tasks. I love beer, coffee, hiking and, of course, hockey.

Title: Talking Loud Or Talking Often: How the Interplay Between Network Structure and Agent Influence Affects the Time to Reach Consensus in Collective Decision-Making
Description: Consensus-seeking processes are core mechanisms for social organization in non-human animal groups, human societies, artificial and multi-agent systems. Such processes consist of a series of negotiations between individuals, which ultimately aggregate different individual opinions into one common agreed decision. Related works have shown that a small number of influential and highly centralized agents i.e. leaders, considerably speed up the consensus-seeking process. Yet the important features of hierarchy and leaders have not been clearly identified and their investigation in experiments provide contradictory evidence. To disentangle these effects, we separate two features of hierarchy (i) the level of centralization ν and (ii) the number of leaders NL, i.e. influential individuals. We therefore developed a continuous opinion formation model to explore the effect of each feature and their interplay on the time to reach a global consensus. The results show that the most important feature is the topology of the network structure, with higher centralization always decreasing the time to reach consensus. In addition, it also demonstrates that the effect of influential individuals are deeply entangled with the underlying network structure. Indeed, it can be beneficial to have a few leaders if the structure is centralized, but surprisingly it can also be detrimental if the population is homogeneous. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation of the “babble” hypothesis which stresses the importance of talkativeness and extraversion of leaders. Further directions involve a full characterization of the main mechanisms leading to polarization or fragmentation as final states in more complex network structures, such as modular structures with nested hierarchies.

Name: Gianrocco Lazzari
Biography: After a MSc in theoretical physics in Utrecht (NL), I moved to biology in Basel (CH) for a short period. I am currently doing my PhD in public health at EPFL (Lausanne, CH). My work mostly involves statistical data analysis and mathematical modeling. I am passionate about mountain sports, latin dances and sustainability.

Title: Quantifying Transmission and Identifying Factors Associated with the Malaria Outbreak in Venezuela
Description: Our analyses provide a quantitative examination of the current malaria outbreak, both within Venezuela, and its impact on neighboring countries.
Name: Gianrocco Lazzari
Biography: After a MSc in theoretical physics in Utrecht (NL), I moved to biology in Basel (CH) for a short period. I am currently doing my PhD in public health at EPFL (Lausanne, CH). My work mostly involves statistical data analysis and mathematical modeling. I am passionate about mountain sports, latin dances and sustainability.

Title: Spatio-Temporal Patterns of Smallpox Epidemics in the United States from 1915 to 1950
Description: Here we use a large dataset of historical smallpox cases, complied under Project Tycho, to assess the presence of spatio-temporal patterns in US smallpox outbreaks.

Name: Aleksandra Aloric
Biography: I'm Aleksandra Alorić, a physicist/mathematician by education. I am interested in collective behaviour in all sorts of systems, but I mostly worked on financial systems and the evolutionary game theory. I am really passionate about outreach and more broadly role of scientists in the society. I like making stuff (like modular origami and earrings) I love microactivism and street art and I hope to combine the two to nudge some societal changes.

Title: Modeling the Dynamics of Wealth Inequality
Description: In this work, we propose a theoretical framework to study the evolution of wealth inequality in a given population. We consider, among other things, demographic variations, policy effects, and other types of inequality. In addition, we present an agent based model to simulate some of the dynamics of wealth inequality.
Name: Eleonora Mavroeidi
Biography: Eleonora is an economist at the Economics Department of the OECD, and previously worked at the International Department of the Bank of England and the Research Departments of the IMF and World Bank. Eleonora’s research interests include economic modelling, international macroeconomics and trade. She holds a Masters in Economics from Brown University (USA), and a Masters and Bachelor in Mathematics from University of Warwick (UK).

Title: The Impact of Technology Intervention on the Sustainable Development Goals
Description: This project builds on recent work addressing the interconnections among SDG indicators using a complexity and network theory approach. We take a technology-focused view and investigate the effects of introducing a new or improved technology portfolio into an existing network of resources, technologies, and industries.
Name: Sanna Ojanpera
Biography: Sanna is a DPhil Student at the OII and also a doctoral student at the Alan Turing Institute, where she leads the Data and Inequality interest group together with her supervisor Mark Graham.

Title: Industrial Economic and Spatial Clustering in Singapore
Description:
Using the clustering network detected in the first stage of the study, we examined the relationship between economic linkages
and spatial clustering across and within industrial sectors. To address this, cluster matching analysis was conducted to study
the strength of the relationship between both types of clustering network. This study found that the economic and geographical
clustering activity exhibit global similarity of approximately 0.6, which suggests that on a broad level, the economic linkages and
spatial clustering of industrial sectors tend to be correlated. Lastly, pairwise asymmetric comparison between industries in the
broad sector was proposed to evaluate if industries grouped together in the spatial cluster were also grouped together in the
economic clusters.
Topic_isced: Social and behavioural science; Architecture and building
Name: Sanna Ojanpera
Biography: Sanna is a DPhil Student at the OII and also a doctoral student at the Alan Turing Institute, where she leads the Data and Inequality interest group together with her supervisor Mark Graham.

Title: A Quantitative Approach to Contact Improvisation Dance
Description:
Partner improvisation is characterized by prediction, adaptation and emergent outcomes that are
unique to the pair. These definitions have not been stringently applied to improvisational dance,
therefore we propose a way to measure the influence of partners on the emergent movements of
each other. As a pilot study, we use a simple alphabet of body contact (torso, arms, legs) to code
3 videos of improvisation pairs. We record the point of contact for each partner, and then use this
information to compute measures of mutual information and entropy rate. We find that mutual
information between partners is higher as the level of the improvisation grows, which is consistent
with our understanding of prediction in improvisation. Our study finds that the level of experience
in contact improvisation of the annotator makes a difference when scoring the contact between
partners. Entropy rate calculations have a big bias due to shortage of data, and do not distinguish
between the pairs of dancers.
Name: Alexandra Mikhailova
Biography: I am a PhD student in neuroscience at UC Davis. I am excited to add complexity science to my study of neuroimmune interactions in developmental neuroscience.

Title: Translating from Nature to Technology: Framework to Compare Innovation Pathways in Biomimicry
Description: Biomimicry is a growing area of research that seeks to abstract functions and architectures observed in nature to solve problems in science and engineering. Previous studies have documented biomimicry efforts in individual subfields, and discussed the philosophical foundations of biomimicry as a sustainability-oriented innovation strategy. Less work has been done, however, on describing the individual steps of abstraction taken in the course of biomimicry innovation efforts. Studying this question can add to an understanding of how the process of replicating or mimicking nature works in practice, and whether successful outcomes result from similar inputs. Here we begin to address this gap by compiling a database of the most widely discussed biomimicry applications. We use this database to develop a conceptual framework to describe the process through which biological phenomena have been translated into technologies (Fig. 1).
Name: Alexandra Mikhailova
Biography: I am a PhD student in neuroscience at UC Davis. I am excited to add complexity science to my study of neuroimmune interactions in developmental neuroscience.

Title: A Study on Public Transport Mobility Flows in Singapore
Description: In this study, a subset of data comprising of one day of public transport (PT) journeys from commuter card records from Singapore was analyzed to understand the PT mobility network structure (see Figure 1, left panel) and detect community clustering within the city-state at the broad level.
Name: Jared Edgerton
Biography: Jared Edgerton is a PhD student in the Department of Political Science at Ohio State University. Jared is interested in political violence, international conflict, terrorism, transnational organized crime, and complex system modeling. His current projects include studying the effects of unexploded ordnances on post-conflict development, the motivations of suicide terrorists, the effect of exogenous shocks on different network structures, the co-appearance networks of pundits from 2000 to 2010, and the differences between single and repeat offenders during the Rwanda Genocide. Jared's methodological research interests include network inference, machine learning, Bayesian statistics, and complex system modeling.

Title: Nighttime Light, Superlinear Growth, and Economic Inequalities at the Country Level
Description: Research has highlighted relationships between size and scaled growth across a large variety of biological and social organisms, ranging from bacteria, through animals and plants, to cities an companies. Yet, heretofore, identifying a similar relationship at the country level has proven challenging. One reason is that, unlike the former, countries have predefined borders, which limit their ability to grow “organically.” This paper addresses this issue by identifying and validating an effective measure of organic growth at the country level: nighttime light emissions, which serve as a proxy of energy allocations where more productive activity takes place. This indicator is compared to population size to illustrate that while nighttime light emissions are associated with superlinear growth, population size at the country level is associated with sublinear growth. These relationships and their implications for economic inequalities are then explored using high-resolution geospatial datasets spanning the last three decades.
Topic_isced: Architecture and building; Mathematics and statistics
Name: Ore Koren
Biography: I am a pre-doctoral fellow at the Dickey Center at Dartmouth College, and a former Jennings Randolph Peace Scholar at the United States Institute of Peace, specializing in international relations and methodology. Starting August 2018, I will join the faculty at the Department of Political Science, Indiana University, Bloomington. My work has appeared or is forthcoming in multiple academic journals, and has been mentioned in numerous policy outlets.

Title: Modeling the Dynamics of Wealth Inequality
Description: In this work, we propose a theoretical framework to study the evolution of wealth inequality in a given population. We consider, among other things, demographic variations, policy effects, and other types of inequality. In addition, we present an agent based model to simulate some of the dynamics of wealth inequality.
Name: Javier Garcia-Bernardo
Biography: Javier Garcia-Bernardo is a PhD candidate in Political Science at the CORPNET project. He did his M.Sc. in Computer Science at the University of Vermont (USA), specializing in Complex Systems. He is interested in understanding the influence of corporate networks in the real world. Javier’s work focuses on unveiling the structure and dynamical properties of such networks, and connecting those properties to real-world effects.

Title: Collective Information Processing in Human Rumor Spreading Networks: An experimental Study of Rumor Content Fusion and Propagation
Description: We posit that this difference is largely due to the fact that classical laboratory experiments do not take into account complex interaction mechanisms in human societies. Namely, ways in which groups can combine noisy information to reduce overall uncertainty. We design an experimental setup intended to allow the observation and quantification of such mechanisms, which have been shown to be important in other collective information processing systems. The effect of feedback introduced into the rumor spreading process through redundant transmission pathways in a network structure is investigated. The scale of our experiments is not large enough to give statistically significant results with regards to the importance of network structure However, motif analysis of our results shows that non-trivial information fusion mechanisms are employed by human participants when presented with con accounts of a rumor. We hope that the work presented in this report will pave the way to future experiments and models of information fusion, which will allow us to quantify how human societies collectively process information in the form of rumors.

Title: Resilience in Conway's Game of Life
Description: Resilience to environmental challenges is one of the hallmarks of life. The goal of this project would be to search for patterns in Conway's Game of Life that can cope with external perturbations and self-organize back into their original forms. Conway's Game of Life[1] is a cellular automaton that has raised a lot of attention due to the life-like forms that it generates. Cellular automata are computational models composed of a grid of cells that can be on either of two (or more) states. At every generation, each of these cells can change according to the state of their neighbours. Interestingly, Conway's Game of Life is Turing-complete, meaning that it can compute any computable function, including the Game of Life itself [2]. For this reason, one should expect to find a wide range of interesting patterns, including those that can detect external perturbations and repair themselves. By finding them, we would be providing a compelling example of one of life's key traits as an emergent behaviour in a simple computational environment.

Title: Production Webs in Minecraft
Description: Map the web of natural resource use in Minecraft and its hierarchy of dependencies, including the potentially circular dependencies (ie you need spider silk to make a bow, which you can then use to kill spiders). Can then infer which resources are most used, their trophic level, and what tools are required to produce them.
Name: Chris Quarles
Discipline_isced: Social and behavioural science; Mathematics and statistics
Biography: My research interests focus around inequality and opportunity, and how they are affected by changes in technology and how we group ourselves. I'm a PhD student in Information at the University of Michigan. My academic background is in math and physics. My interest in complex systems comes from working in them for over a decade as a community college math professor. Name: Ian Lim
Biography: Ian is a researcher involved in sampling methodology, statistical modelling, and data science projects.

Title: Scrutinizing Early Warning Signals of Depression
Description: Historically, depression has been understood within a 'common cause' framework in which the associations between symptoms such as worry, sadness, and lack of sleep is due to an underlying latent variable. This is an extremely successful approach in medicine, where symptoms usually are due to some underlying biological disease. In psychology, this has been less successful. An emerging 'network perspective' instead abandons the assumption of an underlying common cause and views depression as arising out of symptoms that directly influence each other, that is, as a complex system. There has been some work on 'early warning signals' which indicate 'tipping points', i.e., transitions to an alternative stable state. This project aims to extend and critically evaluate how these approaches have been applied to predict the onset and termination of depression.

Title: Teamwork Makes the Dream Work: Analyzing Interdisciplinary Collaboration at CSSS
Description: How has the nature of collaboration at CSSS changed over time? Using project and participant data from the last 20 years of the program, we plan to explore how topics and group structures have changed over time. Have groups become more interdisciplinary? Is there a pattern to the types of projects that individuals from particular fields tend to work on?

A little over a year ago, I started a PhD at the University of Amsterdam, working on Bayesian testing, causal inference, and time-series analysis. Besides academic things, I’m thinking about how we can utilize people’s quantitative skills for the social good, and have started local initiatives in that sector. I am also a terrible, but enthusiastic, chess player and enjoy bouldering.

Title: Teamwork Makes the Dream Work: Analyzing Interdisciplinary Collaboration at CSSS
Description: How has the nature of collaboration at CSSS changed over time? Using project and participant data from the last 20 years of the program, we plan to explore how topics and group structures have changed over time. Have groups become more interdisciplinary? Is there a pattern to the types of projects that individuals from particular fields tend to work on?
Name: Emily Coco
Biography: I am a doctoral student in the Department of Anthropology at New York University. My current research focuses on understanding recycling in archaeological contexts, particularly the scavenging of stone tools, through the use of agent-based models. Additionally, the fieldwork component of my research is focused on Paleolithic Central Asia, with my most recent excursions taking me to Kazakhstan.

Title: Intersections of CSS and CBR
Description: We are reviewing the existing literature to examine the intersections of community-engaged research and complex systems science research. Specifically, we are examining: (1) How is community-based research used in complex systems science? And (2) How is complex systems science used in community-based research?
Name: Robert Coulter
Biography: As a public health researcher, my mission is to reduce substance use and violence inequities for sexual and gender minority youth (SGMY; i.e., lesbian, gay, bisexual, or transgender youth). I conduct three lines of inquiry: epidemiologic, intervention, and complex systems science research. My research agenda focuses on: improving knowledge of the complex social mechanisms producing SGMY health inequities; and increasing knowledge about the impact of interventions on health inequities for SGMY.

Title: Intersections of CSS and CBR
Description: We are reviewing the existing literature to examine the intersections of community-engaged research and complex systems science research. Specifically, we are examining: (1) How is community-based research used in complex systems science? And (2) How is complex systems science used in community-based research?
Name: Winnie Poel
Biography: I am a PhD candidate in theoretical biology with a masters in physics and some research experience in social psychology. In my work, I use network models of (complex) social contagion to understand how schools of fish collectively process information. My special interest is in the evolution of the network structure and it's function in the spread of information.

Title: Intersections of CSS and CBR
Description: We are reviewing the existing literature to examine the intersections of community-engaged research and complex systems science research. Specifically, we are examining: (1) How is community-based research used in complex systems science? And (2) How is complex systems science used in community-based research?
Name: Travis Moore
Biography:
I investigate how complex systems science can be used to increase deep resident engagement in community-embedded initiatives. I study multi-level health systems from the ground up using structural modeling and social network techniques. To this end, I am currently evaluating a state-wide public health initiative to understand how changes in network structure align with desired health outcomes. 

I am also interested in how gatekeeping influences research projects involving multiple levels of stakeholders. I am currently writing a grant that would look at how power, control, and other aspects of gatekeeping might moderate/mediate the outcomes of research projects and evaluation outcomes.

Title: Intersections of CSS and CBR

Name: Dee Romo
Biography: Glory Dee Romo just finished her PhD at The University of Queensland, Brisbane, Australia. Her masteral degree was on Management at the University of the Philippines Mindanao while her undergraduate program was BS Business Economics at the University of the Philippines Diliman. She also completed two graduate diplomas in Economics and Econometrics. She is currently teaching at the University of the Philippines Mindanao and is the Master in Management Program Coordinator.

I work with food webs and other ecological networks from both theoretical and empirical perspectives. I'm excited to learn about and work with networks beyond ecology, and to network with people beyond ecology!

Name: Shihui Feng
Discipline_isced: Social and behavioural science; Mathematics and statistics
Biography: Shihui Feng is a lecturer at the University of Hong Kong. Her research interest is to study social behavior with network theories and methods.

Title: Weighted Expectations
Description:
Applying Valence-Weighted Distance (VWD), a novel probability weighting function developed by Mikaela, to a dynamic asset pricing model to explain emergent aggregate behavior.

Probability functions are applied in the context of non-expected utility theories to explain deviations of individual decision makers from the predictions of expected utility theory. A plethora of research has found that people tend to overweight small probabilities and underweight larger probabilities -- however, the psychological bases of this tendency remain unclear.

Grounded in psychophysics, VWD builds on information theoretic principles and aims to provide a psychological explanation for the shape and parameter fits of existing probability weighting functions (Tversky & Kahneman, Prelec, LinLog). In addition, VWD introduces novel (empirically testable) predictions, is sensitive to choice context, and has less free parameters than existing probability weighting functions.
Topic_isced: Social and behavioural science; Mathematics and statistics
Name: Mikaela Akrenius
Discipline_isced: Social and behavioural science; Mathematics and statistics
Biography: I am a fourth year PhD student in Cognitive Science at Indiana University Bloomington. My general interests lie in the intersection of intelligence, rationality, and cognitive process models of decision making. My current projects investigate the role of perceptual processes in likelihood inference and risk taking and the psychological roots of non-expected utility theories. In my free time, I compose small pieces for piano and keyboards and orchestrations for heavy metal bands.

Biography: I am a PhD candidate in Network Theory at the University of Oxford. I am passionate about promoting Women in STEM and I am a committee member of the Women in Engineering Society. I grew up in Albania, did my undergraduate in Italy, my MSc in France, and, currently, I study and live in Oxford, UK. My hidden passion is cooking. Tiramisù is my signature dish!

Title: Explaining mass extinction driven dwarfing (lilliput effect) with metabolic scaling theory
Description: After every mass extinction event there is a reduction in the body size of animals before recovery. How can we explain this from first principles?

Biography: I am currently a PhD student in Behavior, Ecology, Evolution and Systematics (BEES) at the University of Maryland, College Park. I received my undergraduate degree from the Indian Institute of Science (IISc), Bangalore, India. I have a major in Physics, and minors in Biology and Earth Science. Currently, I am using mathematical methods to probe into mass extinction events in deep geological time.

Title: Multi-scale Inequality & Cities
Description: Increases in inequality and urbanization are two of the challenges facing global sustainable development. However, inequalities in the urban context are conventionally understood by analyzing one city at a time, which limits a multi-scalar understanding. This project proposes to investigate whether there are general patterns in how inequalities manifest across spatial scales and regional contexts and examine the relationships between urban networks and inequalities.

Name: Daniel Borrero
Biography: Daniel Borrero is Assistant Professor of Physics at Willamette University, a small liberal arts college in Salem, OR. He received his BS from UT-Austin and his PhD from Georgia Tech. His research focuses on understanding the subcritical transition to turbulence in shear flows and other fluid mechanical systems with complex spatiotemporal dynamics. In the past, he has studied synchronization in mechanical systems and symmetry reduction methods for dynamical systems with continuous symmetries.

Title: Self-Organizing Cities
Description:
Exploring emergence and how a city can evolve and be shaped by social interactions. Planned cities and organically developed cities all have a network of public spaces. This looks at the use of agent based modelling and adaptive networks to study both the formation and resilience of public space networks in cities.

How do do public spaces and active functions of the city influence the flow of people?

Title: Too Much Information and Segregation
Description: Every entity has a limited capacity to process information. So, when there is too much information, entities need to exclude information that does not benefit them. What happens when there are increases in the amount of information available, such as when technology allows a place-based society to transition to a more connected one? Individuals will have more options, and will also need to be more selective about the information they receive. Does this lead to increased segregation and/or specialization in a social system and/or biological system? We are approaching these questions using a network model, where nodes update their filters based on a utility function.
Topic_isced: Social and behavioural science; Mathematics and statistics

Biography: My main research interests are human decision-making and its neural underpinnings. Under this umbrella, I use theory from computer science (computation theory) to provide insights into meta-decision making and in particular, into the cognitive resource allocation process in the brain. I study how resource constraints affect human behaviour and how humans, and their brains, cope with these biological limitations.

Name: Brennan Klein
Biography: Brennan is a 4th-year PhD student in Network Science. He studies how complex systems are able to represent, predict, and intervene on their surroundings across a number of different scales—all in ways that minimize the surprisal experienced in the future. He is currently working on a dissertation examining the teleology of networks, or why there appears to be an apparent purpose or goal-directedness to the dynamics and structure of networks.

Title: Topological diversity in networks
Description: We are studying both the relationship between generative mechanisms and emergent topology of network ensembles and the diversity of topological properties within subsamples of networks. The aim is to probe for a new conceptual landscape for understanding complexity in network topologies. We hypothesise that network topologies derived from social and biological systems are characterised by an inability to infer the topology of one part of the network given knowledge of other parts, as opposed to random and ordered systems in which such inference is far easier.
Name: Keith Smith
Biography: I focus on developing mathematical tools to illuminate hidden interdependencies of large biomedical datasets that will help to understand disease processes and enhance classification strategies. This focuses on utilising graphs and networks, including analyses of brain structural and functional connectivity, as well as looking to integrate analysis of multi-modal data across the anatomy.

Name: Toni Pichler
Biography: I am a PhD student in Maths at the University of Oxford (supervised by JD Farmer). I am based at the Institute for New Economic Thinking (INET) and also affiliated with the Complexity Science Hub. My research interests lie in the field of complexity economics. I have worked on the minimization of systemic risk in financial markets, but my PhD is centered around technological progress. I want to take advantage of production and technology networks to predict progress in individual technologies.

Title: The individual lives of microbial cells: evolution of phenotypic diversity in a bacterial population
Description: Scientists tend to appreciate microbes for their simplicity and predictability: if you put a population of genetically identical cells in a uniform environment, we assume they will all behave in the same way. However, in many cases this assumption is catastrophically wrong. We're frequently discovering new examples of clonal microbial populations that show diversity in a particular phenotype-- say, growth rate, substrate preference, or antibiotic tolerance-- in a way that is seemingly stochastic (not a case of plasticity in response to the environment). In some cases, this diversity may simply be noise with little consequence for the ecology of the population. In others, it seems to be an evolved trait, often in response to environmental stress, that confers increased fitness on the population as a whole even if some individuals are not behaving in an optimal way. How does phenotypic heterogeneity evolve? In what environments is it advantageous for all cells to behave the same way, and in what environments is diversity beneficial? How does the nature of the environmental stress influence the shape of the phenotypic distribution that will evolve? Can we call it "bet-hedging" or "division of labor"? We are using agent-based modeling to explore these questions-- focusing first on the example of bacterial colonies growing in the face of antibiotic stress, but with the aim of building a generalizable model that can draw connections among different types of organisms and environments.
Name: Jessica Lee
Biography: I study microbial ecology and evolution, with a special interest in understanding the individual lives of microbial cells. I'm a postdoc at a small nonprofit research institute in San Francisco, in the Boundaries of Life Initiative, which focuses on understanding the fundamentals of what it means to be biological. I'm also adjunct faculty at San Francisco State University. I love teaching, and talking about microbes to all who will listen.

How does the nature of the environmental stress influence the shape of the phenotypic distribution that will evolve? Can we call it "bet-hedging" or "division of labor"? We are using agent-based modeling to explore these questions-- focusing first on the example of bacterial colonies growing in the face of antibiotic stress, but with the aim of building a generalizable model that can draw connections among different types of organisms and environments.
Name: Adam Reynolds
Biography: I am a Ph.D. student in Evolutionary Anthropology at the University of New Mexico. My research combines approaches from behavioral ecology and complex systems science to build theoretical models of human biology and social behavior that can be rigorously tested through quantitative ethnographic fieldwork. I am currently studying gender disparities in health in female-centered societies and the dynamics of inequality on social networks. My fieldwork takes place in China, Vanuatu, and Mauritius.

Title: The individual lives of microbial cells: evolution of phenotypic diversity in a bacterial population
Description: Scientists tend to appreciate microbes for their simplicity and predictability: if you put a population of genetically identical cells in a uniform environment, we assume they will all behave in the same way. However, in many cases this assumption is catastrophically wrong. We're frequently discovering new examples of clonal microbial populations that show diversity in a particular phenotype-- say, growth rate, substrate preference, or antibiotic tolerance-- in a way that is seemingly stochastic (not a case of plasticity in response to the environment). In some cases, this diversity may simply be noise with little consequence for the ecology of the population. In others, it seems to be an evolved trait, often in response to environmental stress, that confers increased fitness on the population as a whole even if some individuals are not behaving in an optimal way. How does phenotypic heterogeneity evolve? In what environments is it advantageous for all cells to behave the same way, and in what environments is diversity beneficial? How does the nature of the environmental stress influence the shape of the phenotypic distribution that will evolve? Can we call it "bet-hedging" or "division of labor"? We are using agent-based modeling to explore these questions-- focusing first on the example of bacterial colonies growing in the face of antibiotic stress, but with the aim of building a generalizable model that can draw connections among different types of organisms and environments.
Name: Ritwika Vallomparambath PanikkasserySugasree
Biography: I am a 4th year graduate student in Physics at the University of California, Merced. I am broadly interested in foraging problems and my thesis is focused on predator -prey systems with scavenging processes incorporated. I love travelling, lifting, and lazy Sundays.

Name: Pam Mantri
Biography: Interdisciplinary Researcher looking to apply Complexity Sciences in the study of Complex Adaptive Cancer Governance. Inspired by the (periodic-table like) Human Cell Atlas initiative, is there perhaps a comprehensive CAS process atlas within which Cancer resides and successfully evades Immuno-Genetic surveillance? Could cancer be cartographically tracked across a family of CAS processes that comprehensively spans multiple scales (micro-meso-macro)?

Name: Daniel Borrero
Biography: Daniel Borrero is Assistant Professor of Physics at Willamette University, a small liberal arts college in Salem, OR. He received his BS from UT-Austin and his PhD from Georgia Tech. His research focuses on understanding the subcritical transition to turbulence in shear flows and other fluid mechanical systems with complex spatiotemporal dynamics. In the past, he has studied synchronization in mechanical systems and symmetry reduction methods for dynamical systems with continuous symmetries.

Name: Kirtus Leyba
Biography: I am a Ph.D student at Arizona State University. In my academic career I have studied Astrophysics and more recently Computer Science. I am interested in emergent behavior in complex systems with simple rules. I am particularly interested in evolution, artificial life, and network security.

Title: Modeling and predicting food insecurity using a resilience lens
Description: Over 800 million people are hungry today, and vulnerable to drought, floods and crop-disease driven by climate change. I’m interested in modeling the incidence of hunger as a dynamic, stochastic system using a resilience lens. Would like to see if we can predict the incidence of hunger in response to shocks using a neural net.
Name: Erwin Knippenberg
Biography: Dr. Erwin Knippenberg is Lead Economist at Cooper/Smith, a DC-based startup using data to drive innovations in public health and food security. Erwin has a PhD in Applied Economics from Cornell University, where he wrote his dissertation on resilience and food security in the context of climate change. As a consultant at the World Bank, he used machine learning algorithms to inform poverty targeting. Prior to Cornell Erwin was an ODI Fellow at the Liberian Ministry of Finance.

I’m interested in modeling the incidence of hunger as a dynamic, stochastic system using a resilience lens. Would like to see if we can predict the incidence of hunger in response to shocks using a neural net.
Name: Andrew Gillreath-Brown
Biography: I am a PhD candidate in the Department of Anthropology at Washington State University working with Dr. Tim Kohler. My dissertation research (as part of the openSKOPE.org project) focuses on producing and evaluating paleoclimatic models that in turn influence maize productivity estimates in agent-based simulations. These data can be used to better understand changes in demography and explore a variety of questions surrounding social and cultural responses to climate change.

Name: Dan Krofcheck
Biography: I am a research assistant professor at the University of New Mexico, Department of Biology. Over the past five years, I have focused my research on how change in the structure of semi-arid ecosystems affects how the landscape interacts with light, water, and energy.

Name: Fabian Dablander
Discipline_isced: Social and behavioural science; Mathematics and statistics
Biography: I have received a Master's degree in Cognitive Science from the University of Tübingen, Germany. A little over a year ago, I started a PhD at the University of Amsterdam, working on Bayesian testing, causal inference, and time-series analysis. Besides academic things, I’m thinking about how we can utilize people’s quantitative skills for the social good, and have started local initiatives in that sector. I am also a terrible, but enthusiastic, chess player and enjoy bouldering.

Title: Complexity & Consent
Name: Jackie Brown
Discipline_isced: Social and behavioural science; Architecture and building
Biography: I am an MES candidate studying urban planning at York University. I am interested in how changes to our economic and social infrastructure can combat growing isolation and facilitate the formation of self-organizing communities.

Title: Complexity & Consent
Name: Elissa Cohen
Biography: Elissa is a second year Economics doctoral student at American University. Her research broadly focuses on the intersection of public economics and choice under uncertainty. When not contemplating economic flows, you can find Elissa side-hustling as a vinyasa yoga instructor (flows of a different sort!).

Title: Complexity & Consent
Name: Travis Moore
Biography:
I investigate how complex systems science can be used to increase deep resident engagement in community-embedded initiatives. I study multi-level health systems from the ground up using structural modeling and social network techniques. To this end, I am currently evaluating a state-wide public health initiative to understand how changes in network structure align with desired health outcomes. 

I am also interested in how gatekeeping influences research projects involving multiple levels of stakeholders. I am currently writing a grant that would look at how power, control, and other aspects of gatekeeping might moderate/mediate the outcomes of research projects and evaluation outcomes.

Title: Complexity & Consent
Name: Ernest Aigner
Biography: Ernest Aigner, MSc. is PhD candidate at the Department for Socioeconomics at Vienna University of Business and Economics (WU). His interests lie at the intersection of social, ecological and political-economic concerns. Currently he works on paradigmatic orientations in economics examining a large-scale citation network covering articles published in economics in the last 60 years.
Affiliation: Vienna University of Economics and Business

Title: Exploring climate belief dynamics in social networks
Description:
The landscape of political thought is constantly changing, and whenever a new idea or policy enters the public discourse people must form an opinion about it based upon their existing belief system and the opinions of others in their social network. Sometimes the public reaches a majority consensus about a given issue. Other times no consensus is formed, and the population is split into relatively stable ideological factions instead.

Our goal is to answer some/all of these questions:

When are people susceptible to adopting new ideas based upon their existing belief system?
How much easier is it for central nodes to spread ideas than nodes that are not connected to many others?
When does a minority belief become a majority consensus opinion, and when does a population split into opposing factions?
How does this model apply to real-world political opinion dynamics, possibly including polling data on same-sex marriage and climate change?
Topic_isced: Social and behavioural science; Environmental protection
Name: David Gier
Biography: I am a PhD student in physics at the University of California, Davis. My research focuses on quantifying structure and entanglement in quantum systems, including applications in quantum computing, communication and materials.

Name: Kyle Furlong
Discipline_isced: Social and behavioural science; Mathematics and statistics
Biography: I am a data scientist in the MITRE Corporation’s Model-Based Analytics Department. Prior to coming to MITRE, I obtained my MSPPM–Data Analytics from Carnegie Mellon University’s Heinz College and my BA in Mathematics and Music from Gettysburg College. Professionally, I love developing interactive web visualizations to tackle challenging, ill-defined problems. When not working, I enjoy trail running, arranging songs for choirs, and travelling.

Title: Resilence and presilience in protein network structure
Description:
What happens when one introduces a novel piece of information to a semi structured system? Is the information purged, incorporated, or persist neutrally. There is a neat study of how networks seemingly become more redundant over time, specifically, the data describes protein interaction network across ~1800 species. Idea is to re-create this data and play around with it, ideally to check how the structure of the network may influence whether or not a new protein can be incorporated.

Why proteins? Mutations are the source of evolutionary novelty. Without evolutionary novelty, an organism will struggle to adapt to an alternating environment. Simultaneously, mutations are perceived to mostly be deleterious, causing negative fitness effects. Effectively, we are facing an evolutionary balance act between maintaining current functionality (selection against deleterious mutations), but also incorporating novelty (mutations, diversity) in order to stay opt in a constantly alternating environment. So, how can a systems incorporate novel information, without breaking the current functionality? You can think of proteins as a network of friends, and friends who introduce you to new friends. The practical nature of proteins, is that they have limited personality, thus they are easier to model. At least so we imagine.
Name: April Kleppe
Biography: Born and raised in Stockholm, did my BS and MSc in Norway, specialised in evolutionary ecology. Made a discipline shift to bioinformatics, as I wanted to understand the molecular mechanisms that underlie novel traits. I am in my 4th year of my PhD of evolutionary biology. I am looking into translational errors during protein synthesis. I am generally interested in how errors may either distrub the information trajectory in a cell, or rather may novel information.

Name: Brennan Klein
Biography: Brennan is a 4th-year PhD student in Network Science. He studies how complex systems are able to represent, predict, and intervene on their surroundings across a number of different scales—all in ways that minimize the surprisal experienced in the future. He is currently working on a dissertation examining the teleology of networks, or why there appears to be an apparent purpose or goal-directedness to the dynamics and structure of networks.

Name: Keith Smith
Biography: I focus on developing mathematical tools to illuminate hidden interdependencies of large biomedical datasets that will help to understand disease processes and enhance classification strategies. This focuses on utilising graphs and networks, including analyses of brain structural and functional connectivity, as well as looking to integrate analysis of multi-modal data across the anatomy.

Name: Laura Stolp
Biography: I am a graduate student at the University of Amsterdam, where I study Cognitive Neuroscience. I have a very broad interest regarding a variety of topics. Currently, the topic that interests me most concerns how the sense of self arises from the brain. Another topic that really interests me has to do with how opinions spread through social networks and how this influences the public opinion, development of ideologies, policies and more.

Biography: I am a graduate student in the Department of Integrative Biology at the University of Texas at Austin with Mark Kirkpatrick and Claus Wilke. I am broadly interested in genome evolution, the evolution of sex and sex determination, phylogenetic inference, and protein evolution. For my dissertation, I am interested in implementing novel methods to understand how genomes evolve under sexual reproduction.

Name: Doug Reckamp
Biography: Assistant Professor of National Security Studies at the National War College in Washington D.C. Naval Officer and former Commanding Officer of USS TOLEDO (SSN 769) Nuclear Powered Fast Attack Submarine. B.S. degree in Mech Eng from US Naval Academy 1990. M.S. degree in Mech Eng from UT Austin 1992. M.S. degree in National Security Studies from National War College 2012.

Name: Anshuman Swain
Biography: I am currently a PhD student in Behavior, Ecology, Evolution and Systematics (BEES) at the University of Maryland, College Park. I received my undergraduate degree from the Indian Institute of Science (IISc), Bangalore, India. I have a major in Physics, and minors in Biology and Earth Science. Currently, I am using mathematical methods to probe into mass extinction events in deep geological time.

Title: Is entropy sexy?
Description: We are interested in studying bird species with complex courtship displays to understand how the predictability of a display is correlated with mating success. Individual birds may vary the sequence or types of moves in a display to attract a mate. However, it is not known whether males with more or less predictable dances fare better. A given performance may be unpredictable with respect to the preceeding steps in the sequence or to a canonical performance that forms the basis for most displays in that species. Using Shannon entropy, we will develop a measure of surprise (within a sequence) and novelty (relative to canonical sequence) in courtship displays and apply it to a dataset of annotated performances where the subsequent mating success of performers is known. By characterizing the role of unpredictability in courtship displays, we hope to shed light on the cognitive and aesthetic dimensions of mate choice.
Name: Kenzie Givens
Biography: Kenzie Givens is a first year PhD student in Evolution, Ecology and Behavior and Complex Networks and Systems. Originally from Los Angeles, CA, she received her B.A. in Biology from Reed College in 2017. Kenzie is currently working with Professor Matthew Hahn and Rafael Guerrero to model how the architecture of gene regulatory networks constrains the evolution of gene expression. Other interests include coevolution on dynamic and rugged fitness landscapes, higher-order epistasis and robustness-evolvability tradeoffs.

Title: Is entropy sexy?
Description: We are interested in studying bird species with complex courtship displays to understand how the predictability of a display is correlated with mating success. Individual birds may vary the sequence or types of moves in a display to attract a mate. However, it is not known whether males with more or less predictable dances fare better. A given performance may be unpredictable with respect to the preceeding steps in the sequence or to a canonical performance that forms the basis for most displays in that species. Using Shannon entropy, we will develop a measure of surprise (within a sequence) and novelty (relative to canonical sequence) in courtship displays and apply it to a dataset of annotated performances where the subsequent mating success of performers is known. By characterizing the role of unpredictability in courtship displays, we hope to shed light on the cognitive and aesthetic dimensions of mate choice.
Name: Henri Kauhanen
Biography: I'm a post-doc at the University of Manchester, UK, working on mathematical and computational models of cultural evolution, more specifically language change. Current research topics extend from simplified analytical models (in the fashion of evolutionary game theory) to more realistic agent-based simulations and the use of big data in the study of linguistic variation and change.

Name: Ritwika Vallomparambath PanikkasserySugasree
Biography: I am a 4th year graduate student in Physics at the University of California, Merced. I am broadly interested in foraging problems and my thesis is focused on predator -prey systems with scavenging processes incorporated. I love travelling, lifting, and lazy Sundays.

Name: Pablo Flores
Biography: I am a graduate student at the University of California, Davis. From an interdisciplinary perspective, my research interests focus on communication dynamics within complex social systems. Currently, I am working on a model to understand the cycle of collective emotions in the aftermath of a natural disaster. In my free time I enjoy soccer and tennis, always in the mood if someone wants to scuba dive.

Title: Evaluating Two Mechanisms for the Evolution of Social Complexity
Description: Theorists from Herbert Spencer to Brian Arthur assert that evolution drives an upward spiral of complexity, but the devil's in the details. How, exactly, does this process work? Presumably, multiple mechanisms operate and their relative importance varies from system to system. Focusing on a single type of systems, viz. social systems, this project aims to assess two competing accounts of the social evolution of complexity. Both hypotheses posit a feedback process by which group selection determines basic cultural/social features (see diagram). One camp, call them `pure cultural evolutionists', identifies the primary link as that between group functionality and social-moral rules. By contrast, a second group, `gene-culture evolutionists', asserts that the most important feedback links group functionality with the human genome. These theories are compatible, even complementary, but a question remains as to which provides a better explanation of the recent, massive increase in social complexity. To compare these two processes, we draw on a recently compiled composite measure of social complexity (whitehouse et. al.) as well as data on the evolution of the human genome and the evolution of social norms. We hypothesize that gene-culture evolution is far too slow to adequately explain the rapid and massive increase in social complexity, while pure cultural evolution provides a more satisfying account.
Name: Alexander Schaefer
Biography: Alex Schaefer is a PhD student in philosophy at The University of Arizona. His research interests include law and economics, social contract theory, and the history of political ideas. Alex earned a BA in philosophy and economics from the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

Name: Dries Daems
Biography: I have a Ph.D. in Archaeology and am generally interested in studying long-term trajectories of social complexity, socio-ecological resilience, urbanization, and agent-based modeling. I studied at KU Leuven (Belgium) and recently worked on a postdoctoral project at Koç University (Turkey). Outside of work, I love playing football (not the American type), running, reading books and playing the guitar.

Name: Marjorie Ylisiurua
Biography: PhD student at University of Helsinki, Finland. I investigate endogenous reasons for phase transitions in consumer interest, applying mixed and computational social science methods to a Finnish social media data set. I have worked as an industry researcher since completing my Masters in Electronic Engineering, and a B. Soc. Sc. I have often worked with Finnish pioneers, both in business and academic Internet research, and I am a co-founder in the national Internet researchers’ learned society.

Name: Ignacio Garnham
Biography: As a Transdisciplinary Design MFA candidate, my research broadly concerns with the role of design in mediating the emergence of complex phenomena in social, biological, and artificial systems. I am particularly interested in design’s capacity to dictate both how social constructs evolve together with society, and how societies perceive (possibilities for) change as social constructions evolve.

Name: Kazuya Horibe
Biography: Kazuya Horibe is currently a Ph.D. student in Theoretical Biology lab, Osaka University. He is studying computational biology, artificial life in the graduate school of Osaka University, after finished Bachelor’s degree in biological science in Osaka University and Master’s degree in information science in Osaka University.

Title: Cultural fractals: Evidence for punctuated equilibria and other themes in a time series of online interaction
Description: We are examining a 83M row social media dataset to better understand evolving human community interaction over the course of sixteen years (2001 - 2017 and ongoing). The forum is an old-fashioned message board with a hierarchical structure. Its unique characteristic is that as the discussion evolves, discussion topic areas are divided into new ones by human moderators. These label the new areas, thus giving the subareas meaning and shaping the future of the community discussion frames. Contrary to many social datasets in current use, there is no visible network structure in this dataset, because participants mostly are not registered nor do they have a network of friends.

Name: Winnie Poel
Biography: I am a PhD candidate in theoretical biology with a masters in physics and some research experience in social psychology. In my work, I use network models of (complex) social contagion to understand how schools of fish collectively process information. My special interest is in the evolution of the network structure and it's function in the spread of information.

Name: Jessica

Title: Network Control with Graph Signal Processing
Description: Once one discovers how the structure effects the function of a network, a possible next consideration is controllability of the network. For control to be possible, one must have a reliable map of the interactions occurring between nodes, a formulation of the dynamical equations governing the behavior of each node, and the capability to effect change in the behavior and state of some collection of the nodes. We will examine the roles that network topology and dynamical equations play in the context of network controllability. Our particular interest is in how noise induced on the network topology or dynamics will influence controllability. A few examples of systems relevant to this line of inquiry could include regulatory processes in cells or economies and the operation of power grids.
Name: Alec Kirkley
Biography: I am a graduate student at the University of Michigan working on network theory, specifically models for network sampling and inference. I am excited to collaborate with people from a multitude of disciplines and see how we can work together to approach real world problems with statistical methods, within or outside the realm of networks.

Name: Billy Braasch
Biography: As a graduate student in physics, I study the interface between the quantum and classical worlds. I’m working to generate quantum states of a near-macroscopic string. I study properties of quantum dynamics that may lead to new schemes for quantum state stabilization in the presence of a noisy environment. Sustainability is another passion of mine and I hope to turn this into an academic pursuit with complexity science as a launching point. I love to climb rocks of all sizes and cook!
