Name: Brennan Klein
Biography: Brennan is a 4th-year PhD student in Network Science. He studies how complex systems are able to represent, predict, and intervene on their surroundings across a number of different scales—all in ways that minimize the surprisal experienced in the future. He is currently working on a dissertation examining the teleology of networks, or why there appears to be an apparent purpose or goal-directedness to the dynamics and structure of networks.

Name: Harun Siljak
Biography: I'm a Marie Curie Fellow at CONNECT Centre, Trinity College Dublin, working on complexity and control in distributed large antenna arrays. I observe massive antenna arrays as complex systems and devise distributed control algorithms which exploit emergence and reduce computational complexity by harnessing systemic complexity. My research interests include physics of computation, reversibility, wave propagation and nonlinear dynamics.

Title: Game Warping
Description: What if players can transform a noncooperative game to a cooperative positive-sum game? This is possible in certain digital economic systems (such as those on a blockchain) because all contracts are strictly enforceable. These type of "game-warping" transformations are interesting because given any economic model with pre-defined rules, the agents are able to develop unforeseeable cooperation strategies, form coalitions, and expand the scope of potential actions over time. Effectively, players are collectively able to overturn the system dynamics. The economy evolves because the economic rules effectively change w/ time (anyone play Baba Is You?). "Game warping" is defined as using transparent, triggerable, unstoppable punishments to move game-theoretic equilibria. We can extend this to multiple players and model the system using a graph/network, to explore what different cooperation strategies emerge. I trust that studying these systems at a macro-level, using simulations or networks will bring greatest degree of insight and set this research apart. David Wolpert's (SFI) work on "game mining" is also relevant.
Topic_isced: Social and behavioural science, Mathematics and statistics
Name: Shruti Appiah
Biography: Shruti is a product and research lead at ConsenSys. She pioneered in studying cryptoeconomies through the lens of complex systems, creating the first multi-agent simulations of economic systems on Ethereum. This year, she was named Canada's top 30 under 30 developers. Her alma mater is in Systems Design Engineering at the University of Waterloo. She enjoys traveling, giving talks and seminars, and cooking.

Name: Aabir Abubaker Kar
Biography: A mechanical engineer, physicist, complex systems scientist, wannabe social scientist, and coder. Studied in India at BITS Pilani, with research experience at NECSI, MA and TIFR Bangalore. Interested in the ubiquity of patterns in social, economic, and behavioral observations. Enjoys debate, poetry, soccer, and making music.

Title: Science Policy and Communication
Description: How is information transferred from scientists to policymakers to constituents? How much information is lost in translation from scientific papers to news articles and tweets? This group will explore the (potential) information loss along each transition, along with other policy-based issues that will emerge from the interaction between scientists and policymakers.
Topic_isced: Social and behavioural science; Mathematics and statistics
Name: John Malloy
Biography: I am a second year PhD student at Arizona State University, where I study the origin of life here on Earth and what it can tell us about potential life in the universe. My research focuses what makes the biochemical reactions within life different than the inorganic reactions outside of life. To that end, I study the evolution of the chiral nature of biochemical compounds as a means of distinguishing life from non-life.

This group will explore the (potential) information loss along each transition, along with other policy-based issues that will emerge from the interaction between scientists and policymakers.
Topic_isced: Social and behavioural science; Mathematics and statistics
Name: Chris Boyce-Jacino
Biography: I'm a third year PhD student in Behavioral Decision Research at Carnegie Mellon University. My research revolves around how people relate to one another — how they seek and share information, how they try to infer the intentions of others, how they try to communicate intentions of their own. To this end, I play with cognitive psychology, computational linguistics, and economics.

Drawing on my technical background and theory from Science and Technology Studies, I investigate the ways in which social factors shape the scientific process, and how science goes on to shape culture and society.

Name: Mackenzie Johnson
Biography: I am a graduate student in the Department of Integrative Biology at the University of Texas at Austin with Mark Kirkpatrick and Claus Wilke. I am broadly interested in genome evolution, the evolution of sex and sex determination, phylogenetic inference, and protein evolution. For my dissertation, I am interested in implementing novel methods to understand how genomes evolve under sexual reproduction.

Name: Kyle Furlong
Discipline_isced: Social and behavioural science; Mathematics and statistics
Biography: I am a data scientist in the MITRE Corporation’s Model-Based Analytics Department. Prior to coming to MITRE, I obtained my MSPPM–Data Analytics from Carnegie Mellon University’s Heinz College and my BA in Mathematics and Music from Gettysburg College. Professionally, I love developing interactive web visualizations to tackle challenging, ill-defined problems. When not working, I enjoy trail running, arranging songs for choirs, and travelling.

Name: Andrew Gillreath-Brown
Biography: I am a PhD candidate in the Department of Anthropology at Washington State University working with Dr. Tim Kohler. My dissertation research (as part of the openSKOPE.org project) focuses on producing and evaluating paleoclimatic models that in turn influence maize productivity estimates in agent-based simulations. These data can be used to better understand changes in demography and explore a variety of questions surrounding social and cultural responses to climate change.

Title: Lingua Technica
Description: Technology and language are related—words like "delete", "reboot", and "reset" only became prominent in our language with the introduction of computing. In other cases, language adopts metaphors of technology such as in phrases like "I'm Dying", "I'm losing you", and "They act like a robot". In this project we will analyze the uptake of such terms in English language text over the past decades. We hope to assess the extent and speed to which technical metaphors are adopted in a variety of mediums. We We will begin with words relating to computing and extent to other technologies such as cars, medicine, and more.

Biography: Jeongki Lim is Assistant Professor of Strategic Design and Management at Parsons School of Design at the New School. His research focuses on self-organization, immersive technology, and decision making.

We We will begin with words relating to computing and extent to other technologies such as cars, medicine, and more.
Name: Pablo Flores
Biography: I am a graduate student at the University of California, Davis. From an interdisciplinary perspective, my research interests focus on communication dynamics within complex social systems. Currently, I am working on a model to understand the cycle of collective emotions in the aftermath of a natural disaster. In my free time I enjoy soccer and tennis, always in the mood if someone wants to scuba dive.

Title: Lingua Technica
Description: Technology and language are related—words like "delete", "reboot", and "reset" only became prominent in our language with the introduction of computing. In other cases, language adopts metaphors of technology such as in phrases like "I'm Dying", "I'm losing you", and "They act like a robot". In this project we will analyze the uptake of such terms in English language text over the past decades. We hope to assess the extent and speed to which technical metaphors are adopted in a variety of mediums. We We will begin with words relating to computing and extent to other technologies such as cars, medicine, and more.
Name: Doug Reckamp
Biography: Assistant Professor of National Security Studies at the National War College in Washington D.C. Naval Officer and former Commanding Officer of USS TOLEDO (SSN 769) Nuclear Powered Fast Attack Submarine. B.S. degree in Mech Eng from US Naval Academy 1990. M.S. degree in Mech Eng from UT Austin 1992. M.S. degree in National Security Studies from National War College 2012.

Title: Taming the Complex via Concept Mapping
Description: While complexity has predominantly been studied as an inherent aspect of nature, it could also present itself as an epistemological transient. This project surveys Prof. Novak's Concept Mapping approach [1] as an epistemological means towards taming complexity. Concept Mapping may also viewed from a Complex Adaptive Systems framework.
Name: Pam Mantri
Biography: Interdisciplinary Researcher looking to apply Complexity Sciences in the study of Complex Adaptive Cancer Governance. Inspired by the (periodic-table like) Human Cell Atlas initiative, is there perhaps a comprehensive CAS process atlas within which Cancer resides and successfully evades Immuno-Genetic surveillance? Could cancer be cartographically tracked across a family of CAS processes that comprehensively spans multiple scales (micro-meso-macro)?

Title: Taming the Complex via Concept Mapping
Description: While complexity has predominantly been studied as an inherent aspect of nature, it could also present itself as an epistemological transient. This project surveys Prof. Novak's Concept Mapping approach [1] as an epistemological means towards taming complexity. Concept Mapping may also viewed from a Complex Adaptive Systems framework.
Name: Dee Romo
Biography: Glory Dee Romo just finished her PhD at The University of Queensland, Brisbane, Australia. Her masteral degree was on Management at the University of the Philippines Mindanao while her undergraduate program was BS Business Economics at the University of the Philippines Diliman. She also completed two graduate diplomas in Economics and Econometrics. She is currently teaching at the University of the Philippines Mindanao and is the Master in Management Program Coordinator.

Name: Wenqian Yin
Biography: Wenqian Yin received the B.S. degree from Jiangsu University, Zhenjing, China in 2011 and the M.S. degree from Hohai University, Nanjing, China in 2015. She is currently pursuing a Ph.D. degree in Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, The University of Hong Kong, Hongkong, China. Her research interests include planning of power system with renewable energy sources.

Title: Artificial fossilization of animal interaction networks
Description: There has been a rapid increase in the number of papers applying network analysis to ancient communities, inferred from the fossil record. However, many of these studies don't account for the fact that the fossil record is incomplete. For example, most soft-bodied organisms don't preserve well. We hope to ground-truth investigations of past processes by analyzing how information loss affects the structure of modern interaction networks (co-occurrence, food webs, etc) and the inferences we make from them.
Name: Jack Shaw
Biography: Graduate student in the Geology and Geophysics department at Yale University. Studying paleoecological trends across the Phanerozoic (~541 Ma to the present).

Name: Kate Wootton
Biography: I am a third year PhD student in Ecology at the Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences in Uppsala, Sweden. I work with food webs and other ecological networks from both theoretical and empirical perspectives. I'm excited to learn about and work with networks beyond ecology, and to network with people beyond ecology!

Name: Andrew Gillreath-Brown
Biography: I am a PhD candidate in the Department of Anthropology at Washington State University working with Dr. Tim Kohler. My dissertation research (as part of the openSKOPE.org project) focuses on producing and evaluating paleoclimatic models that in turn influence maize productivity estimates in agent-based simulations. These data can be used to better understand changes in demography and explore a variety of questions surrounding social and cultural responses to climate change.

Name: Anshuman Swain
Biography: I am currently a PhD student in Behavior, Ecology, Evolution and Systematics (BEES) at the University of Maryland, College Park. I received my undergraduate degree from the Indian Institute of Science (IISc), Bangalore, India. I have a major in Physics, and minors in Biology and Earth Science. Currently, I am using mathematical methods to probe into mass extinction events in deep geological time.

Name: Dries Daems
Biography: I have a Ph.D. in Archaeology and am generally interested in studying long-term trajectories of social complexity, socio-ecological resilience, urbanization, and agent-based modeling. I studied at KU Leuven (Belgium) and recently worked on a postdoctoral project at Koç University (Turkey). Outside of work, I love playing football (not the American type), running, reading books and playing the guitar.

Name: Emily Coco
Biography: I am a doctoral student in the Department of Anthropology at New York University. My current research focuses on understanding recycling in archaeological contexts, particularly the scavenging of stone tools, through the use of agent-based models. Additionally, the fieldwork component of my research is focused on Paleolithic Central Asia, with my most recent excursions taking me to Kazakhstan.

Title: Toward an effective control of malaria in Ghana
Description: Malaria is a vector-borne disease endemic to many countries in Africa as well as in Asia. This disease results from an interaction between Anopheles gambiae (mosquito), Plasmodium falciparum (parasite) and the human (host). Since Ross division of the host population in purely homogenous compartments, many variants of the model were used to get insights into the transmission and some strategy to control the disease. Thanks to such a simplistic representation of the epidemic, malaria control is remaining since 1950 a nightmare for policymakers since the disease is still persisting though numerous control measures were applied. This study aims at testing the dilution theory while accounting for the spatial repartition of the disease incidence using an adaptive ABM.
Name: Koissi Savi
Biography: Koissi Savi is a Ph.D. student in the One Health Graduate School, Bonn- Germany. He intends for his Ph.D. to develop a multi-scale compartmental model explaining the endemicity of malaria in a fast-growing urban setting integrating ground realities.

Name: Bhartendu Pandey
Biography: Doctoral Candidate at the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies. My research focuses on the intersection of global urbanization and environmental change.

Title: Codename Leaf Hunters
Description: Previous work has identified quantitative measurements of leaves such as persistent homology, machine learning (e.g. CNNs), and fractal dimensionality as a method to predict the phylogenetic origin of leaves (a classification task of whether the leaf belongs to the species or not). Although interesting, we find this work isn’t useful for building theoretical models of plants within their environments. It is an interesting question whether environmental complexity (however that is measured!) might have relationships to leaf complexity (however that is measured!). This analysis could be useful for developing knew understandings into how and why complexity emerges in plant evolution.
Name: Levi Fussell
Biography: I am a PhD student at the University of Edinburgh where I study population models with large numbers of agents. Within this domain, my research includes how self-assembling dynamics can occur in nature, to what processes drive cooperation in a competitive ecosystem.

Title: Computational Synesthesia
Description: What data comprises the meaning of a word? Extant approaches to automated text analysis assume that the meaning of words can be inferred by examining co-occurrence relations (the bag-of-words approach) and formal semantic relationships among words (the linguistics approach). However, a large body of work illustrates that meaning is multimodal; i.e. words gain their meaning through their use in embodied multimodal contexts as labels that refer to “sensory images” – a property of meaning long known to artists, as in the use of visual imagery to inspire linguistically-mediated interpretations in the domain of painting, or in the use of words to evoke mental representations of sensory images in the domain of poetry. Here we propose a method for automated textual analysis that clusters words not based on text-to-text relations, but rather, in text-to-image relations, based on the structure of the sensory images associated with words. Specifically, we develop an automated approach for using large-scale search data from Google to retrieve a continuous set of images associated with search terms, and we provide information-theoretic measures for clustering search terms based on similarities in the color profile (such as ‘palette’) of . We explore how this clustering method can reveal novel dimensions of meaning previously unavailable through purely text-based methods of automated text analysis, for example, by finding unexpected similarities among search terms based on their color profile, or by providing novel measures for how abstract a word is based on the diversity of images associated with its use as a search term.
Name: Douglas Guilbeault
Biography: Doug is a graduate student in the Network Dynamics Group at the Annenberg School for Communication, Upenn, working with Damon Centola. His dissertation uses agent-based simulations and large-scale online social network experiments to study how people collaboratively construct category systems for novel phenomena. He enjoys hiking, running, poetry, philosophy, meditation, and making music.

Name: Bhargav Srinivasa Desikan
Biography:
Currently a graduate student at the University of Chicago, finishing an MA in Computational Social Science, and doing my research at the Knowledge Lab. I work broadly in two fields - science of science, and ethics/fairness in Machine Learning and AI. always down to talk about the social/ecological ramifications of AI and technology, and am interested to see how the fields of Sociology and Philosophy interact with Computer Science.

I enjoy being part of the open source python scientific computing community: conducting workshops at PyCons/PyDatas and contributing to python NLP libraries like Gensim and spaCy. I've written a book on how to do text analysis in Python, authored the python package pycobra, and have published in the Journal of Machine Learning Research.

(also like to boulder and hike, hang out with my cat, read, and really really enjoy music and dancing!)

Name: Aabir Abubaker Kar
Biography: A mechanical engineer, physicist, complex systems scientist, wannabe social scientist, and coder. Studied in India at BITS Pilani, with research experience at NECSI, MA and TIFR Bangalore. Interested in the ubiquity of patterns in social, economic, and behavioral observations. Enjoys debate, poetry, soccer, and making music.

Name: Mark Chu
Biography: Mark Chu is an Australian painter who shows internationally. His work focuses on abstraction via color and form, using the human face as subject. In the past Mark recorded as a solo pianist with Australian symphony orchestras, and was a restaurant critic. Currently Mark engages in public art for urban renewal in Atlantic City. Mark has a writing M.F.A. from Columbia University. Mark hopes to use findings in Complexity to establish an exhaustive classification system of art with taxonomical rank.

Name: Ruggiero Lo Sardo
Biography: Ruggiero is working on his PhD in the EU Horizon 2020 SmartResilience. In this framework he is investigating the health-care system with supervision by Peter Klimek.

Name: Ethan Nadler
Biography: I'm a fourth-year Physics Ph.D. student at Stanford University. My work focuses on understanding the nature of dark matter using modern galaxy surveys and state-of-the-art simulations, and I'm interested in applying techniques from computational cosmology to problems in complexity science.

Title: HTG in Robotic Swarms
Description: This project explores the possibility of using inspirations of biology to train and evolve swarms of robots to do useful tasks. We are particularly taking advantage of horizontal gene transfer (HTG) that allows microbial populations to adapt without neccessarily reproducing or mutating in the traditional sense. We are interested in the question of how biological processes can be simulated in a static size robot population that cannot grow, die, or reproduce.
Name: Kirtus Leyba
Biography: I am a Ph.D student at Arizona State University. In my academic career I have studied Astrophysics and more recently Computer Science. I am interested in emergent behavior in complex systems with simple rules. I am particularly interested in evolution, artificial life, and network security.

Name: Jessica Lee
Biography: I study microbial ecology and evolution, with a special interest in understanding the individual lives of microbial cells. I'm a postdoc at a small nonprofit research institute in San Francisco, in the Boundaries of Life Initiative, which focuses on understanding the fundamentals of what it means to be biological. I'm also adjunct faculty at San Francisco State University. I love teaching, and talking about microbes to all who will listen.

Name: Mackenzie Johnson
Biography: I am a graduate student in the Department of Integrative Biology at the University of Texas at Austin with Mark Kirkpatrick and Claus Wilke. I am broadly interested in genome evolution, the evolution of sex and sex determination, phylogenetic inference, and protein evolution. For my dissertation, I am interested in implementing novel methods to understand how genomes evolve under sexual reproduction.

Title: The Perfect Door: Design & Science
Description: Push or Pull? A perennial question in the design world, tackled by a combination of design research and complex system methodologies.
Name: Jeongki Lim
Biography: Jeongki Lim is Assistant Professor of Strategic Design and Management at Parsons School of Design at the New School. His research focuses on self-organization, immersive technology, and decision making.

Title: The Perfect Door: Design & Science
Description: Push or Pull? A perennial question in the design world, tackled by a combination of design research and complex system methodologies.
Name: Kenzie Givens
Biography: Kenzie Givens is a first year PhD student in Evolution, Ecology and Behavior and Complex Networks and Systems. Originally from Los Angeles, CA, she received her B.A. in Biology from Reed College in 2017. Kenzie is currently working with Professor Matthew Hahn and Rafael Guerrero to model how the architecture of gene regulatory networks constrains the evolution of gene expression. Other interests include coevolution on dynamic and rugged fitness landscapes, higher-order epistasis and robustness-evolvability tradeoffs.

Title: The Perfect Door: Design & Science
Description: Push or Pull? A perennial question in the design world, tackled by a combination of design research and complex system methodologies.
Name: Luther Seet
Biography: I am an architect and researcher, interested in complexity in urban systems, and also computational methods in the design of architecture and urban spaces.

Title: Scaling of water resources in US cities
Description:
With allometric scaling and resource constraints, we will try to model urban density based on fresh water availability. Our findings will have implications for sustainable development. This project patterns off of Kempes, C. P., West, G. B., Crowell, K., & Girvan, M. (2011). Predicting maximum tree heights and other traits from allometric scaling and resource limitations. PLoS One, 6(6), e20551.

This research demonstrates how cities grow in response to available natural resources. We propose a scalar law based on resource constraints to predict urban growth. Our research has policy implications for considering future sustainable urban growth in the context of fresh water scarcity. By using water use, urban population, total irrigated agricultural land, and available precipitation in watersheds, we are able to develop a scalar relationship to predict total water usage for total, nonelectric water use.
Topic_isced: Architecture and building; Mathematics and statistics
Name: Catherine Brinkley
Biography: Dr. Brinkley’s research centers around One Health, a concept that considers health shared among humans, animals and the environment. She is a veterinarian (VMD) and a city planner (PhD) who conducts spatial analyses to inform practice. Her work focuses on how agricultural and urban lands interface, and the public health consequences.

PLoS One, 6(6), e20551.

This research demonstrates how cities grow in response to available natural resources. We propose a scalar law based on resource constraints to predict urban growth. Our research has policy implications for considering future sustainable urban growth in the context of fresh water scarcity. By using water use, urban population, total irrigated agricultural land, and available precipitation in watersheds, we are able to develop a scalar relationship to predict total water usage for total, nonelectric water use.
Topic_isced: Architecture and building; Mathematics and statistics
Name: Jessica Brumley
Biography: I am a National Research Council postdoctoral fellow doing research on green stormwater infrastructure impacts on groundwater in Oklahoma. My PhD is in Environmental Science from the University of Oklahoma (“Application of Ecosystem Energetic Indicators for the Valuation of Ecosystem Services”) and a B.S. in Biology (“Adaptive Radiation in Experimental Microcosms”) from the University of Houston. Primary research interests have included ecological engineering, system dynamics, and ecosystem thermodynamics. I start as an Assistant Professor in Environmental Science at East Central University (Ada, OK) this fall.

Title: Scaling of water resources in US cities
Description:
With allometric scaling and resource constraints, we will try to model urban density based on fresh water availability. Our findings will have implications for sustainable development. This project patterns off of Kempes, C. P., West, G. B., Crowell, K., & Girvan, M. (2011). Predicting maximum tree heights and other traits from allometric scaling and resource limitations. PLoS One, 6(6), e20551.

Title: Concave Utility as Efficient Encoding
Description:
Analogously, it is well established within economics and psychology that the utility of money (or any other commodity) is concave -- i.e. that decision makers perceive the difference between e.g. $1 and $2 as greater than the difference between $101 and $102. The concavity of utility has been previously explained e.g. with outcome sampling and comparison in the choice environment (Stewart, 2009), the dissociation between large monetary outcomes and outcomes experienced in everyday life, and the notion of the human mind/brain as an efficient transduction system (e.g. Arkes, 1991; Summerfield & Tsetsos, 2015). As far as Mikaela knows, the latter notion has not yet been formally explored outside an experimental context, i.e. through simulating distributions of economic transactions in the actual environment in which decision makers tested in psychological or economic studies make their purchases.

Provisional idea:
Get distributions of economic transactions in different societies
Simulate a decision maker that encodes monetary value optimally given the prevalence of transactions in that society
Compare shapes of resulting utility functions to existing empirical data (observed utility functions)
Topic_isced: Social and behavioural science; Mathematics and statistics
Name: Mikaela Akrenius
Discipline_isced: Social and behavioural science; Mathematics and statistics
Biography: I am a fourth year PhD student in Cognitive Science at Indiana University Bloomington. My general interests lie in the intersection of intelligence, rationality, and cognitive process models of decision making. My current projects investigate the role of perceptual processes in likelihood inference and risk taking and the psychological roots of non-expected utility theories. In my free time, I compose small pieces for piano and keyboards and orchestrations for heavy metal bands.

Name: Elissa Cohen
Biography: Elissa is a second year Economics doctoral student at American University. Her research broadly focuses on the intersection of public economics and choice under uncertainty. When not contemplating economic flows, you can find Elissa side-hustling as a vinyasa yoga instructor (flows of a different sort!).

Title: Sci-Fi ABM-Thology
Description: An anthology of popular science fictions, explored in Agent-Based Models. How to start a rebellion in the total surveillance society of Orwell's 1984? Is it a case for an agent-based model, or maybe a network, or a cellular automaton? Could an emergent strategy bring down the Death Star? What made the Battle of Winterfell so wrong? This project investigates the great narratives of fiction and fantasy through complex systems modelling.
Name: Andrew Gillreath-Brown
Biography: I am a PhD candidate in the Department of Anthropology at Washington State University working with Dr. Tim Kohler. My dissertation research (as part of the openSKOPE.org project) focuses on producing and evaluating paleoclimatic models that in turn influence maize productivity estimates in agent-based simulations. These data can be used to better understand changes in demography and explore a variety of questions surrounding social and cultural responses to climate change.

Name: Harun Siljak
Biography: I'm a Marie Curie Fellow at CONNECT Centre, Trinity College Dublin, working on complexity and control in distributed large antenna arrays. I observe massive antenna arrays as complex systems and devise distributed control algorithms which exploit emergence and reduce computational complexity by harnessing systemic complexity. My research interests include physics of computation, reversibility, wave propagation and nonlinear dynamics.

Title: Models and Metaphors
Description: This project is a discussion group on how we as scientists use different modes of interpretation to draw inferences/conclusions in our research. Basically, in our work, we always use a continuum of frameworks of interpretation, ranging from very general metaphors for system dynamics and changes, to very formal mathematical models describing a very specific process or state. Some of the things we would like to explore further include how these modes of interpretation can be connected, and how we could translate general metaphors into specific models, as well as how using specific modes impact the way we construct knowledge and interpretation.

Description: How to work better in interdisciplinary settings! Yuka and Mark will share ten easy tips!
Name: Mark Chu
Biography: Mark Chu is an Australian painter who shows internationally. His work focuses on abstraction via color and form, using the human face as subject. In the past Mark recorded as a solo pianist with Australian symphony orchestras, and was a restaurant critic. Currently Mark engages in public art for urban renewal in Atlantic City. Mark has a writing M.F.A. from Columbia University. Mark hopes to use findings in Complexity to establish an exhaustive classification system of art with taxonomical rank.

Title: Chaotic Brain
Description:
Some of us are looking at chaos in the brain and how state-transitions in EEG waves may relate to learning/uncertainty-reduction/entropy. This refers to what Liz mentioned on day 1, where EEG waves of a healthy brain displayed a qualitative change in dynamics (bifurcation) when a parameter was changed, i.e., from *chaotic to more periodic*, under the influence of specific drugs. We also learned that the rabbit brain, when remembering a familiar smell as opposed to an unfamiliar smell, displayed a switch from chaotic to periodic attractor. We are asking the question of what other events may trigger a qualitative change in dynamics from chaotic to periodic, e.g., meditation, sleep or flow experiences, and what they have in common? The first step is to scan the literature.

Secondly, could it be that the above bifurcations in the brain correspond to human learning and reducing uncertainty in the sense of information theory, i.e., where a state of higher unfamiliarity and novelty corresponds to more chaotic states and familiarity to more periodic states?
Topic_isced: Social and behavioural science; Physical science
Name: Pablo Franco
Biography: My main research interests are human decision-making and its neural underpinnings. Under this umbrella, I use theory from computer science (computation theory) to provide insights into meta-decision making and in particular, into the cognitive resource allocation process in the brain. I study how resource constraints affect human behaviour and how humans, and their brains, cope with these biological limitations.

Another topic that really interests me has to do with how opinions spread through social networks and how this influences the public opinion, development of ideologies, policies and more.

Description: Can opinion dynamics be explained by processes such as Hebbian learning?
Name: Pavel Chvykov
Biography: I'm finishing my PhD in physics, during which I was working with Jeremy England at MIT looking for principles that drive out-of-equilibrium systems towards emergent ordering, with a view towards understanding origins of life. Next, I am keen to apply the insights we learned to other complex systems found in nature and society. I am also very excited about deeper philosophical underpinnings and implications of this work, and insights we can draw from and for our everyday experience.

Title: River networks
Description: Rivers are the arteries of our planet. They cycle nutrients, fluids, and materials over the Earth system, shaping and maintaining a habitable environment that supports life. The phenomenal branching structures of river systems make them ideal objects for network science studies, yet limited communications have been made between the two fields. In this project, geologist Gen, teaming up with network Guru Brennan and Alec (not a network guru), work to unravel the mystery behind the rivers. Aiming at a fundamental understanding of the dynamic nature of rivers, they will tackle the river system from a network science angle, seeking order in the complexity of real-world landscapes.

Biography: Geologist interested in the physical and chemical processes that cycle elements and materials in the earth system. Currently postdoc at Caltech.

Name: Brennan Klein
Biography: Brennan is a 4th-year PhD student in Network Science. He studies how complex systems are able to represent, predict, and intervene on their surroundings across a number of different scales—all in ways that minimize the surprisal experienced in the future. He is currently working on a dissertation examining the teleology of networks, or why there appears to be an apparent purpose or goal-directedness to the dynamics and structure of networks.

I am excited to collaborate with people from a multitude of disciplines and see how we can work together to approach real world problems with statistical methods, within or outside the realm of networks.

Description: Rivers are the arteries of our planet. They cycle nutrients, fluids, and materials over the Earth system, shaping and maintaining a habitable environment that supports life. The phenomenal branching structures of river systems make them ideal objects for network science studies, yet limited communications have been made between the two fields. In this project, geologist Gen, teaming up with network Guru Brennan and Alec (not a network guru), work to unravel the mystery behind the rivers. Aiming at a fundamental understanding of the dynamic nature of rivers, they will tackle the river system from a network science angle, seeking order in the complexity of real-world landscapes.
Name: Dan Krofcheck
Biography: I am a research assistant professor at the University of New Mexico, Department of Biology. Over the past five years, I have focused my research on how change in the structure of semi-arid ecosystems affects how the landscape interacts with light, water, and energy.

Title: Evolution of Cells' Decision to Divide
Description:
How do cells decide when is the right time to divide? From a purely efficiency-based perspective, cells can obtain nutrients at a rate proportional to their surface area, but nutrient requirement for growth has a rate proportional to volume of the cell. Thus, there will be a cell size that is optimum for division.

The problem with this reasoning is, cells will tend to divide at the same size on average, irrespective of their initial size. But we know that in most bacterial species, cells that start out small (large) tend to divide at a size smaller (larger) than the average size at division.

This indicates there is a different reason behind cells’ decision to divide. It is an optimal path chosen by evolution, and I intend to simulate cells susceptible to mutations under different conditions to understand how this division mechanism arises through evolution and why it is optimal.
Name: Kunaal Joshi
Biography: I study biophysics in the Department of Physics and Astronomy. My work mostly involves single cell growth dynamics of bacterial cells, including growth rates in different conditions, cell death under antibiotics, aging and adaptation etc.

Name: Kazuya Horibe
Biography: Kazuya Horibe is currently a Ph.D. student in Theoretical Biology lab, Osaka University. He is studying computational biology, artificial life in the graduate school of Osaka University, after finished Bachelor’s degree in biological science in Osaka University and Master’s degree in information science in Osaka University.

Title: Modelling the spatial diffusion of human language
Description: The diversification of human languages is a bit like speciation in biology: using comparative and cladistic methods, linguists can group languages into language families and further subgroup them into "phylogenetic" trees or networks. At the same time, we know where these languages are spoken today. The question, then: putting these two sources of data together, can we model the diffusion of languages over physical space and work backwards from the present day to infer the most likely homelands of the corresponding protolanguages? Can the predictions of such a model be made to align what we otherwise know about human migrations in the past? And most importantly (I think), from a complex systems perspective: what facets of the processes of linguistic diffusion and diversification are universal (i.e. not due to accidental historical events)? We could start with a simple random-walk model and take it from there.
Name: Henri Kauhanen
Biography: I'm a post-doc at the University of Manchester, UK, working on mathematical and computational models of cultural evolution, more specifically language change. Current research topics extend from simplified analytical models (in the fashion of evolutionary game theory) to more realistic agent-based simulations and the use of big data in the study of linguistic variation and change.

Name: Harun Siljak
Biography: I'm a Marie Curie Fellow at CONNECT Centre, Trinity College Dublin, working on complexity and control in distributed large antenna arrays. I observe massive antenna arrays as complex systems and devise distributed control algorithms which exploit emergence and reduce computational complexity by harnessing systemic complexity. My research interests include physics of computation, reversibility, wave propagation and nonlinear dynamics.

Name: Kenzie Givens
Biography: Kenzie Givens is a first year PhD student in Evolution, Ecology and Behavior and Complex Networks and Systems. Originally from Los Angeles, CA, she received her B.A. in Biology from Reed College in 2017. Kenzie is currently working with Professor Matthew Hahn and Rafael Guerrero to model how the architecture of gene regulatory networks constrains the evolution of gene expression. Other interests include coevolution on dynamic and rugged fitness landscapes, higher-order epistasis and robustness-evolvability tradeoffs.

Name: Pablo Flores
Biography: I am a graduate student at the University of California, Davis. From an interdisciplinary perspective, my research interests focus on communication dynamics within complex social systems. Currently, I am working on a model to understand the cycle of collective emotions in the aftermath of a natural disaster. In my free time I enjoy soccer and tennis, always in the mood if someone wants to scuba dive.

Name: Ritwika Vallomparambath PanikkasserySugasree
Biography: I am a 4th year graduate student in Physics at the University of California, Merced. I am broadly interested in foraging problems and my thesis is focused on predator -prey systems with scavenging processes incorporated. I love travelling, lifting, and lazy Sundays.
